episode_summary: This episode of 'No Such Thing As A Fish' covers a variety of intriguing topics, including the unusual washing habits of the Levi's CEO, the first successful transatlantic flight, the peculiar inheritance of Napoleon's body part, and the cultural significance of sausages in Germany.

facts.fact: The CEO of Levi's, Chip Bergh, hasn't washed his jeans in more than a year.
The first successful transatlantic flight, which happened in 1919, was made by two guys from Manchester who at one point were flying sideways at a 90-degree angle to the surface of the ocean.
In 2007, a woman called Evan Latimer inherited Napoleon's penis from her father.
To say 'I don't care about something,' a German person has the option of saying 'It's sausage to me' or in German, 'Das ist mir Wurst.'
